componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Mike, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Starbucks Coffee Company's First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  Ms. , you may begin your conference.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. This is , Director of Investor Relations for Starbucks Coffee Company. Thank you for joining us today to discuss our first quarter 2016 results, which will be led by Howard Schultz, Chairman and CEO; Kevin Johnso
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. This is , Director of Investor Relations for Starbucks Coffee Company. Thank you for joining us today to discuss our first quarter 2016 results, which will be led by Howard Schultz, Chairman and CEO; Kevin Johnson, President and COO; Michael Conway, President, Global Channel Development; and Scott Maw, CFO. Joining us for Q&A are Cliff Burrows, Group President, U.S., Americas and Teavana; John , Group president, China/Asia Pacific, Channel Development and Emerging Brands; Matt Ryan, Global Chief Strategy Officer; and Adam Brotman, Chief Digital Officer. 
This conference call will include forward-looking statements which are subject to various risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from these statements. Any such statements should be considered in conjunction with cautionary statements in our earnings release and risk factor discussions in our filings with the SEC including our last annual report on Form 10-K. Starbucks assumes no obligation to update any of these forward-looking statements are information. 
Visit our website at investor.starbucks.com to find a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures referenced in today's call with the corresponding GAAP measures.  This call is being webcast, and an archive of the webcast will be available on our website at investor.starbucks.com. 
And with that, I will turn the call over to Howard.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, , and welcome, everyone, to today's call. Starbucks' stellar Q1 2016 financial and operating performance, highlighted by a 9% increase in comp store sales in the U.S. and 8% increase in comp store sales globally, our third sequential quarter
componenttext:
Thank you, , and welcome, everyone, to today's call. 
Starbucks' stellar Q1 2016 financial and operating performance, highlighted by a 9% increase in comp store sales in the U.S. and 8% increase in comp store sales globally, our third sequential quarter of a 4% increase in global traffic by far, the strongest holiday in our history, and record revenues and record operating income from our Channel Development segment, underscores the increasing strength and relevance of the Starbucks brand and the success of the accretive flywheel positive affect of retail, CPG, digital, mobile, loyalty, card, investment strategies around the world that are coming together to accelerate our growth and drive significant margin expansion and EPS leverage across our business. 
In Q1, Starbucks delivered a 12% increase in revenue to a record $5.4 billion and a 15% increase in non-GAAP EPS to a record $0.46 per share, despite the significant investments we continue to make in our partners and in our business. And we served over 23 million more customer occasions from our global comp store base in Q1 and roughly 18 million more customer occasions in the U.S. alone than we did in our very strong Q1 last year.
Starbucks Coffee Company is connecting more deeply with more customers across all day-parts at around the world than ever before. And we are delivering quarter after quarter of record-breaking financial and operating results despite the accelerating shift in consumer behavior away from traditional bricks and mortar retailing and despite challenging macroeconomic foreign exchange, geopolitical and retail and consumer headwinds that continued to negatively impact many other national and global retailers. 
Global leadership around all things coffee and tea and ongoing beverage and food innovation remain at Starbucks' core and are propelling our business forward. In the Q1, we brought further premiumization to the coffee category, creating even greater separation from our competitors and delivered an elevated, highly differentiated, locally relevant premium coffee and tea, beverage food and in-store experience to our customers everywhere.  Our Seattle Roastery continues to delight both regular customers and visitors from around the world to Seattle, at the same time as it performs well ahead of our original expectations and serves as a launching pad for our ultra premiums Starbucks Reserve brand. 
Our plans to build over 500 coffee forward Starbucks Reserves stores in global markets are well underway. Starbucks Reserve stores provide customers with a unique highly premiumized in-store experience that showcases the finest assortment of exclusive Starbucks Reserve single varietals and new specialized coffee brewing methods during intimate one-on-one partner customer experience that takes place as and explains the custom beverage. Starbucks Reserve stores also offers a curated assortment of Teavana teas to increase consumer awareness of Teavana superpremium loose-leaf and packaged teas. And Starbucks Reserve coffee varietals are now also available in several thousand high profile Starbucks stores globally, further elevating both existing Starbucks stores and the Starbucks Reserve brand, while demonstrating a global sourcing capability and diversity of origin that only Starbucks can deliver.
Starbucks' Channel Development segment is literally firing on all cylinders, delivering meaningful share gains and record sales and profitability in Q1. The Starbucks brand now has the lead position and lead market share in both premium roasted ground and premium single-serve on the K-Cup platform. Michael Conway will take you through Channel Development's performance in Q1 shortly. But by creating more opportunities for more people to engage with us more often, both inside and outside of our stores, Starbucks' integrated highly coordinated retail and wholesale strategy is driving our business and our growth around the world.  No national or global retailer has been able to leverage a retail store footprint into a CPG business remotely approaching the size, scale and profitability of ours. Under Mike's leadership, Starbucks' CPG business has become a powerful, fast-growing and highly profitable business and complementary channel of distribution for us. 
By anticipating and investing years ahead of the mobile technology curve, Starbucks today is redefining the customer-facing and partner-facing mobile and retail experiences of the future. In a few minutes, Kevin will take you through how we are leveraging proprietary technology, digital engagement and customer loyalty to create a comprehensive, integrated, digital and mobile ecosystem that will continue to drive our business well into the future. Technology innovation is further strengthening our brand including our efficiency in in-store execution, increasing our profitability and most importantly, enabling us to deliver an elevated Starbucks Experience to our customers, particularly to millennials. 
Starbucks' unique combination of assets includes a growing global physical footprint of now over 23,500 stores; over 300,000 passionate Starbucks partners who proudly wear the Green Apron and who I wish to personally thank for the extraordinary results we report today; breakthrough mobile and digital technologies; and over 190,000 points of CPG distribution all over the world. Together, these attributes are contributing to the strength we are seeing and our business and enabling us to serve over 85 million customer transactions around the world every week, at the same time as we continue to extend our reach and deepen our emotional connection to customers everywhere.
The key to our business and what no other consumer brand or retailer can even approach is the deep authentic connection we have with our customers and our customers have with our people in the Starbucks brand. I experienced this firsthand perhaps like never before on a trip with John Culver to Asia last week. We began in , China, where over 1,300 Starbucks partners and their families joined us at our fourth annual China partner and family forum. It was an extraordinary, emotional event that celebrated the pride and the respect the parents that our partners have for their children and in their children's connection to Starbucks, the deep emotional connection that exists among our China partners themselves and the shared commitment that China have to deliver extraordinary Starbucks Experience to their customers. Joining us to share his respect and admiration for Starbucks at the event and to all Starbucks partners and their families was Jack ma, founder of Alibaba. 
In Q1, we introduced social gifting to China through Alibaba's T-Mobile site to a stunning customer response. And now and for the first -- very first time through T-Mo, our customers in China can give their friends and colleagues digital Starbucks fits, including My Starbucks Rewards membership, individual beverages and preloaded Starbucks digital gift cards. We are honored that the Chinese government chose Starbucks to be the first company in China to be authorized to offer customers a stored value card.
As you know, China has been in the news a great deal lately. As a CEO who has traveled to China repeatedly over the last 10 years, perhaps more than any other American CEO, I have a unique perspective to share. First, let me say that China is here to stay. The that the Chinese economy is taking during today's period of transition is necessary for us to move on the next stage of development. Short-term market gyrations, however, should not be confused with actions that will lead to long-term sustainable economic gain, especially as China moves to a consumer-driven economy. I strongly believe that the Chinese government's commitment to true economic reform is genuine and that its goal of doubling 2010 per capita income by 2021, resulting in a middle class in China approaching 600 million Chinese people or almost twice the size of the entire current U.S. population, is attainable.
We are taking a long-term view on how we will build our business in China. Because despite now having close to 2,000 stores in nearly 100 cities in China and being on track to have 3,400 stores on the mainland by 2019, I am convinced more than ever that Starbucks is just getting started in an important country. And I'm equally convinced that when we fully roll out our digital mobile card gifting and loyalty programs across our business in China and CAP overall and expand the distribution of our ready-to-drink products later this fiscal year, we will perform at even higher levels than we are today.
Following China, we went to India where our business with JV partner Tata, already 80 stores strong, is growing faster on a percentage basis than any other region in the world. And we saw firsthand the excitement consumers have for the Starbucks brand and the deep authentic connections our partners are creating their customers. Starbucks Coffee Company has always and will continue to play the long game with strict adherence to our strategic plan for growing our business and continuing to deliver world-leading financial and operating performance and long-term sustainable profitable growth into the future. 
And that growth will include continued growth of our K-Cup business.  Over the last 5 years, we have invested and built a strong sustainable single-serve business operating on the current K-Cup platform. And today, Starbucks is the leading brand with a leading share on that platform.
Since Keurig announced it was selling itself, we have fielded many questions about our intentions following the sale. I want to assure retailers, the millions of consumers who demand Starbucks-branded coffee to their Keurig brewers, many of whom have told us that they actually purchase the Keurig brewers only after Starbucks Coffee became available on the platform and the market, that we are in the K-Cup business to stay. However, at this moment, the only matter that remains unresolved is whether we will be doing so in conjunction with Keurig or on our own. 
Starbucks is combining unparalleled financial performance with unmatched groundbreaking innovation that is being embraced by customers and our people around the world. And we now have so much on the horizon. Never in 24 years as a public company has the Starbucks brand or business been stronger or more universally relevant and accepted than it is today. And never before have the opportunities lie ahead as -- or our aspirations ever been greater. We remain humble and steadfast in our mission to exceed the expectations of our customers and our partners, to share our success with our people and the communities we serve to create positive social impact, and to continue along our path of building a great engineering company. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Kevin. Kevin?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone. I'd like to build on Howard's comment and share a few observations on the quarter, before asking Mike Conway to discuss the amazing performance Channel Development delivered in Q1. Scott Maw will then take us thro
componenttext:
Thanks, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone. I'd like to build on Howard's comment and share a few observations on the quarter, before asking Mike Conway to discuss the amazing performance Channel Development delivered in Q1. Scott Maw will then take us through the Q1 financials in detail. 
Starbucks' global comp store sales grew 8% in Q1 with 4% coming from increased traffic. This represented our 24th consecutive quarter of comp growth of 5% or greater. As Howard mentioned, we are experiencing significant transaction growth in every geographic region, and that contributed to our strong Q1 performance. 
On our last earnings call, I reinforced the clarity we have around our strategic priorities, investments we are making in the business and the focus we have an operational execution. This clarity and focus is enabling every segment of our business to deliver. Retail, Channel Development and digital are driving the revenue profit increases we are seeing and elevating the Starbucks brand in the mind of consumers the world over. 
This holiday season, we delivered meaningful beverage and food innovation with Holiday Spice and an expanded holiday food platform to enhance the in-store holiday experience. And we leveraged our digital assets to reward our most loyal customers with 5 specialized Merry Monday offers throughout the holiday season. Those offers, combined with the Starbucks for life sweepstakes, this year open only to our MSR members, drove customer traffic and increased MSR loyalty membership.
Retail innovation and digital engagement were then complemented by great execution across all channels, where sales of our package Holiday Blend coffee was particularly strong, our new Christmas Blend reserve coffee quickly sold out, and our K-Cup platforms delivered record dollar share for the quarter.
Starbucks gift cards once again enabled customers to give the gift of choice. And this year, 1 in 6 American adults received a Starbucks Gift Card, up from 1 in 7 last year and 1 in 8 the year before. This holiday, $1.9 billion was loaded on cards in the U.S. and Canada in Q1 alone, up 19% over a year ago. Gift cards led to increased MSR membership and the digital flywheel spins faster and with increased strength and momentum. 
This dynamic was reflected in the performance of each of our segments. Our fast-growing American segment has another very strong quarter, posting 9% comp growth with 4% coming from an increase in traffic. Americas added 171 net new stores in the quarter and 573 net new stores over the past 12 months.  Core offerings in our blended, espresso and iced beverage platforms, including innovation such as Teavana shake and iced Teas and cold brew coffee, delivered double-digit growth in the quarter and drove 4 points of comp in the U.S. Beverage innovation and the sales of Teavana branded handcrafted tea beverages in Starbucks retail each contributed 1 point to the U.S. comp growth. 
And our morning day-part saw its strongest growth in 5 years. Food revenue was up nearly 20% over last year, contributing 3 points of U.S. comp sales in the quarter. Our food business is growing across all day-parts, with Bistro Boxes up 65% and breakfast sandwiches, which is up more than 40% year-over-year.
Our newest class of stores continues to perform extremely well, with first-year average volumes exceeding 1.4 million, while delivering record profitability and return on investment.
Moving on to CAP. The change in ownership of Starbucks Japan, the addition of 281 net new stores in CAP and comp growth of 5% from our existing store base drove CAP revenues up 32%. We remain very bullish on our long-term growth potential in CAP where we now operate over 5,700 stores. And we remain on plan to double our CAP store count to roughly 10,000 locations by 2019. We opened the market in Cambodia, our 16th CAP market in Q1.
One way we are continuing to extend our coffee leadership and around all things coffee in CAP is by expanding our successful Reserve platform, where we now have over 200 stores selling Starbucks Reserve. Operating and financial performance across our CAP Reserve stores is among the highest of any stores across the entire global portfolio. 
As Howard mentioned, China, Starbucks' largest market outside the U.S., remains a very big part of our CAP story. We now operate roughly 2,000 stores on mainland China with a presence in nearly 100 cities. And we are on plan to achieve our goal of having 3,400 stores by fiscal year '19.  As we grow our store footprint, particularly in China, it is important to note that our new class of company-operated stores in CAP is significantly outperforming even the most recent prior class, reflecting both the increasing strength of the Starbucks brand in the region and improved operating leverage, both of which contribute to the great confidence we have and the opportunity that lies ahead for us in the CAP region. 
Our business in Japan continues to be very strong. We are benefiting from solid execution against our plans to leverage the brand and our connection to customers to drive growth across all day-parts in the key Japanese market. Noteworthy is that Q1 was the first quarter in which our stores in Japan are included in our global comps base. The passion and commitment of our partners and CAP is enabling us to deliver a great customer experience that is strengthening our connection with customers and driving our business throughout the region.
Let's move on to EMEA. EMEA segment delivered 1% comp growth, representing its 11th consecutive quarter of positive comps. Fairly strong performance, giving -- given the dramatic decline in consumer and  tourist activity across many of Western Europe's largest cities following the horrific November 15 terrorist attacks in Paris. Business prior to those attacks was strong, and EMEA was on track to have a solid quarter. We recently began to see the effects of the region's resilience and the recovery. we opened a flagship Starbucks Reserve store in London, setting the stage for significant expansion of our Starbucks Reserve platform across the EMEA region in the months and quarters ahead.
EMEA continued to rebalance its store portfolio, ending the quarter with 71% of all EMEA stores now being licensed, up from 63% at the end of Q1 last year. The segment opened 79 net new stores in the quarter, all of which were licensed, including our first store in Kazhakstan, our 36th EMEA market, which opened to a tremendous customer and partner response. We look forward to opening new EMEA markets in South Africa and Luxembourg in 2016.
In addition to strong retail performance, our Channel Development segment delivered record results in the quarter. And we have Michael Conway, who leads Channel Development, to share some highlights. Mike?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good afternoon, everyone.  Channel Development continued its strong momentum and delivered record financial and operating performance in Q1, while connecting more and more people to Starbucks Coffee around the world where they live,
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good afternoon, everyone.  Channel Development continued its strong momentum and delivered record financial and operating performance in Q1, while connecting more and more people to Starbucks Coffee around the world where they live, work and play. We experienced record revenues of $512 million. And we were up 16% over Q1 last year, following a 14% increase in Q4 of fiscal '15. This was driven by strength of our U.S. CPG, ready-to-drink coffee and food service businesses. Our operating income grew 23% in the quarter to $193 million.
In Q1, each of our U.S. at-home coffee segment significantly outpaced the overall category, punctuated by strong in-store execution of our holiday program in the U.S. Just as our Starbucks stores turned red to signal the holidays, Starbucks also turned that aisles red, with nearly 2 out of 3 grocery stores on average having a holiday display in December. In addition, our Limited Time Holiday Blend Coffee in both K-Cup and roast and ground was the fastest-selling coffee in the Starbucks portfolio in the first quarter.  Both the Starbucks roast and ground and Starbucks K-Cup platforms delivered record dollar share for the quarter. Already the leader in premium coffee, total Starbucks grew 16%, more than 5x total category growth, moving Starbucks ahead of Kraft to become the #2 player in all coffee. In addition, Starbucks was the fastest growing coffee company and the largest contributor to category growth.
Starbucks K-Cups posted strong dollar growth of 20% and gained 100 basis points of share to a record 17.2%, making Starbucks yet again the #1 K-Cup brand for the quarter and now also the #1 brand for the full calendar year, while creating further share gap separation from our nearest competitor.  Recently launched Starbucks hot cocoa K-Cups contributed to our share increase, quickly becoming the third fastest moving SKU within our K-Cup portfolio in December. Starbucks roast and ground continues to be the #1 premium coffee brand, with dollar sales growth of 10% and share growth of 160 basis points to a record 27.3% share for the quarter.
Our food service business continues to lead the industry in Q1, with 14% net revenue growth compared to an average industry growth of 2% to 3%. We saw strength across several channels of business including college and university, travel and office coffee as employers are increasingly offering Starbucks as the premium coffee of choice to their employees and their customers. Our Q1 performance was also positively impacted by revenue growth from existing partner accounts, such as Delta Air Lines Lines and the Compass Group.
Turning to ready-to-drink coffee. Our North America coffee partnership with PepsiCo posted excellent results during the quarter. System sales as measured by IRI grew 22%, resulting in 110 basis points share gain in the total liquid coffee and energy segment to 13.4%, driven by new product innovation in our cappuccino and Doubleshot platforms and through expanded distribution. For the full calendar year, Starbucks is now the #8 brand in the liquid refreshment beverage category and ahead of established brands such as Powerade and Sprite. 
Beyond the U.S., we continued to successfully execute against plan to build our global ready-to-drink coffee business. Our partnership in China with is on track for midyear 2016 product launch. And through our newer agreement with PepsiCo Latin America, we will be building distribution in the region during the second half of 2016. We are also increasing our ready-to-drink penetration in EMEA, with momentum building in our most recent launches in 6 Middle East markets.
Our outlook for 2016 remains positive, supported by strong in-store programming and new product launches like Starbucks Latte K-Cup for both coffee and tea. Combined with the strength of the Starbucks brand and the quality of our coffee, we will continue to delight our customers, outpace the category and build upon our leadership position in the market. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Kevin. Kevin?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Key element of our strategy is our Starbucks rewards loyalty program, and with digital engagement. This was another quarter of solid progress. We continue to see broad customer acceptance and adoption of our mobile platform. And the Starbu
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. 
Key element of our strategy is our Starbucks rewards loyalty program, and with digital engagement. This was another quarter of solid progress. We continue to see broad customer acceptance and adoption of our mobile platform. And the Starbucks mobile app has emerged as an evolving platform and a profit driver of its own. 
We increased the number of active MSR members in the U.S. to 11.1 million, up 23% over Q1 last year. We are seeing growth of active MSR customers in markets around the world. 
Customer engagement is also growing. In the quarter, over 21% of total U.S. transactions was paid using the mobile apps, with December accelerating to 22%, and we're seeing further acceleration in the month of January. 
Over 1 million customers in the U.S. used our Mobile Order & Pay capability in the month of December. And those customers averaged approximately 5 mobile orders in a month, driving meaningful revenue growth and incrementality. Usage of Mobile Order & Pay is growing, and we are now processing over 6 million Mobile Order & Pay transactions per month. In many of our busiest stores where morning peak demand is high, Mobile Order & Pay exceeds 10% of total transactions.  And we have just scratched the surface. We have bigger aspirations for digital plan, and we are expanding the digital agenda across 4 key pillars. 
The first is delivery. We are extending Mobile Order & Pay to include a delivery option for customers. Pilots are underway in Seattle and New York City, and we are learning many new things that will help to shape the future of delivery.
Number two, personalized offerings. We have invested in technology to help us better personalize the offers we make our loyalty customer. Will strengthen our customer connection and fuel growth.
Number three, global deployment. We are committed to leveraging these digital experiences in our major company-operated markets and with our licensee partners.
Number 4, digital media. Spotify music capability we launched this week is one example of an integrated digital media experience. We plan to explore additional digital media scenarios that are entertaining and interesting to consumers and that align with our brand. 
The Starbucks digital flywheel is driven by our loyalty program, and membership in My Starbucks Rewards has grown by over 50% in the last 2 years. In 2016, we will be enhancing the Starbucks rewards program and enable our loyalty customers to earn stars in many new and exciting ways. Clarity our strategic priorities in investments combined with a focus on excellence in execution is powering our results.
I'll now hand the call over to Scott to take us through the Q1 financial results in detail. Scott?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin, and good afternoon, everyone.  We kicked off fiscal 2016 that another record-breaking quarter and a continuation of the accelerating momentum we saw in our business throughout 2015. As Howard shared, in Q1, Starbucks operating income increa
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin, and good afternoon, everyone.  We kicked off fiscal 2016 that another record-breaking quarter and a continuation of the accelerating momentum we saw in our business throughout 2015. As Howard shared, in Q1, Starbucks operating income increased 16% year-over-year and exceeded $1 billion in the single quarter for the first time ever. And we delivered a strong operating margin of 19.7%, 60 basis points over last year. Q1 GAAP EPS of $0.46 compares to GAAP EPS of $0.65 in Q1 2015. Noteworthy is that Q1 2015 included a gain of $0.26 on the acquisition of Starbucks Japan.
Excluding certain Starbucks Japan related items, non-GAAP operating margin grew 40 basis points over Q1 of last year to a quarterly record 19.9%. And non-GAAP EPS also increased 15% year-over-year and reached a quarterly record $0.46. For Q1 operating margin, strong sales leverage and favorability in cost of goods sold was partially offset by the impact of our partner and digital investments. Also Q1 revenue growth included 2 points of negative foreign exchange impact, and non-GAAP EPS growth included 5 points of negative foreign exchange impact.
I'll now take you through the individual segment performance in Q1. The Americas, our largest business segment, has never been stronger, driving 14% operating income growth over Q1 last year and contributing a record-high $935 million. Americas operating margin expanded by 80 basis points to 25.1%, also a Q1 record, driven primarily by sales leverage an excellent management around cost of goods sold. 
The margin improvement we saw in Q1 in the Americas is even more significant when considering that the vast scope of our partner and digital investments began in our Q2 last year, so we will not begin lapping those investments until next quarter.  The increase in partner and digital investments is reflected in the details of our margin change, as store operating expenses increased 80 basis points as a percentage of retail revenue, a figure that included 120 basis points of impact from these investments. We see moderate margin expansion in the Americas business for the full year 2016 despite the significant investments we continue to make.
Moving on to our China Asia-Pacific segment. On a GAAP basis, CAP operating income grew 17% over Q1 last year to a new quarterly record of $127 million. GAAP operating margin declined 240 basis points to 19.4% due primarily to the impact of the ownership change for Starbucks Japan, offset by positive sales leverage. On a non-GAAP basis, CAP operating income increased 20% over Q1 last year. Operating margin, excluding the full 330 basis point impact of our ownership change in Starbucks Japan, increased 90 basis points, driven primarily by strong sales leverage and higher your income from our joint venture operations, partially offset by higher store operating expenses.
By way of reminder, our Q1 2015 results in CAP reflect preacquisition joint venture accounting treatment for the first 5 weeks of the quarter. And our stores in Japan are included in our global comp store base in December, consistent with our established policy.  Given the complexity of modeling our CAP segment in the period immediately following the Japan ownership change, I thought it would be helpful to reiterate that factoring in the impact of adding over 1,000 stores in Japan into the fiscal 2016 calculation, we expect CAP comps to land in the mid-single digits. Noteworthy is that our year 1 performance in Japan significantly exceeded assumptions built into our acquisition model on each of comps, revenue and operating income, supporting the tremendous optimism we have around our performance in Japan in the years ahead. Projected revenue growth in CAP would be in the mid-teens for the year, reflecting excellent growth in all of our major markets and a small benefit from the change in Japan ownership, partially offset by ongoing foreign exchange headwinds. We still see CAP margins flat to down slightly compared from '15 levels.  Noteworthy is that we expect Q2 revenue growth in operating margin to be somewhat lower than the average for the year due to the impact of seasonality in our largest CAP markets.
EMEA's operating margins expanded 50 basis points to 15.4%, principally driven by gains on the sale of assets to our licensees, partially offset by some of the margins in our business resulting, from higher cost of goods sold and the impact of lower sales in company-owned stores, especially during holiday. EMEA's performance was particularly strong given the impact of foreign exchange and challenges to top line growth following the tragic terrorist attacks in Paris. The strength and diversity of our EMEA portfolio were further punctuated in Q1 by strong comp performance from our licensed stores, which delivered comp store sales growth in the high single digits.
While operating income in EMEA declined slightly from the prior year to $48 million, the strength in our underlying business and our expectations of a gradual return to normal operating conditions in the region gives us confidence that EMEA operating margins for the full fiscal year 2016 will still approach 15% as we communicated to you last quarter.
Channel Development operating margin increased 210 basis points to 37.7%. And segment operating income reached a quarterly record of $193 million, 23% over Q1 last year. Another record quarter from our North American coffee partnership business with Pepsi and cost of goods sold favorably were the primary driver of Channel Development's margin improvement in Q1.  As Mike mentioned, profitability growth was ahead of expectation due to strong market share gains across all of our key business lines and excellent execution in operations. For the full year, we continue to expect moderate margin expansion in Channel Development over the prior year.
As I stated at the outset, Starbucks had a very strong Q1, with solid revenue growth and impressive margin expansion. For Q2, we are expecting GAAP EPS in the range of $0.37 to $0.38 and non-GAAP EPS in the range of $0.38 to $0.39, representing non-GAAP EPS growth of 15% to 18%.
Let me take a moment to reiterate the EPS ranges for fiscal 2016 we provided to you last quarter: GAAP EPS in the range of $1.84 to $1.86 and non-GAAP EPS in the range of $1.87 to $1.89, including the 53rd week which adds approximately $0.06 to Q4. This represents 18% to 20% EPS growth for the year.
For the full year, foreign exchange is now expected to be a negative impact on revenue growth by 2 points and negatively impact non-GAAP EPS growth by 3 points, each up 1 full point from our previous guidance. Foreign exchange headwinds and our willingness to accelerate and add to our partner and digital investments as we see opportunity are driving our decision not to increase our full year EPS guidance despite overperformance in Q1.
There seems to be some question that we have lowered guidance for the year. As you can see, our full year EPS guidance is completely consistent with last quarter, despite the headwinds I just mentioned.
Revenue growth is also expected to remain within our previous stated range of 10% or greater on a 52-week basis, with the 53rd week adding approximately 2 points to this figure. Given the strong comp performance we experienced this quarter, we remain confident in our ability to again deliver global comp sales growth somewhat above the mid-single digits for the full year. 
We now expect investments in our partners and digital initiatives to total between $275 million and $300 million globally in 2016 compared to approximately $145 million in fiscal 2015. The slight increase from our previous guidance range is driven by digital projects and supported by the strong results we are seeing from our investments to date and significant opportunities that lie ahead for us.
And by driving industry-leading comp growth, record revenues, record profitability and a reduction in partner attrition compared to a 5-point increase in attrition in the industry at large, these investments are continuing to pay off in a very big and demonstrable way. Noteworthy is that while our comp growth overall remains very strong in today's challenging retail environment, comps are the strongest new stores where partner attrition is the lowest, a portion of the deep connection our partners build over time with their customers. And ROIC in Q1 increased by approximately 100 basis points reflecting the fact that the vast majority of our investments are beating our targeted hurdle rates. This applies particularly to a Mobile Order & Pay where expected return continues to be several times our consolidated ROIC.
We continue to expect consolidated operating margin for fiscal 2016 to increase slightly related to 2015 on both a GAAP and non-GAAP basis, reflecting strong revenue growth, sales leverage and increased operating efficiency and performance, partially offset by the impact of increased partner and digital investments.
Moving on to commodities. With 2016 coffee needs nearly fully priced, we continue to expect a slightly favorable impact of the year. We are now beginning to price our coffee needs for fiscal 2017, and we'll provide updates as we lock in volumes. We continue to expect to add approximately 1,800 net new stores globally in fiscal 2016, 700 in the Americas, 910 in China/Asia Pacific and 200 in EMEA. 
outlook for our effective tax rate continues to be between 34%  and 35%. And we still expect capital expenditures of $1.4 billion for fiscal 2016. 
Finally, we increased total cash return to shareholders by more than 20% to over $500 million in Q1. And we have significantly and opportunistically increased our buyback activity since quarter end, given strong cash flows during the holiday period and recent equity market dynamics.
Q1 of fiscal 2016 marks our seventh consecutive quarter of consolidated revenue growth in excess of 10%, our ninth consecutive quarter of operating margin in excess of 15%, and our 12th consecutive quarter of non-GAAP EPS growth greater than 15%. And we see significant opportunities to continue and as appropriate, selectively increase or accelerate investments in order to support this historical level of performance as we drive annual revenues to the $21 billion mark.  The key today, as always, is to identify and to balance the right combination of targeted disciplined growth across the business with appropriate levels of investment necessary to drive and support such growth.
Finally, what is particularly exciting is that despite our recent record performance, we still have clear line of sight on multiple opportunities in each of our segments and around the world to further accelerate top line growth and deliver outsized profits into the future. The team and the strategic framework we have in place, together with our proven ability to execute, gives us confidence that disciplined increases in the speed and the size of our investments when the right opportunities present themselves is smart business and the right thing to do for our customers, partners and shareholders over the long term.  We look forward to updating you on our progress as we move throughout the year. 
With that, we will turn the call back to the operator for Q&A. Operator?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Keith Siegner from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Keith Siegner from UBS.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question for me and thinking about the food attach and direct sales growth rates, because these are monstrous numbers. If we think about what's driving this -- and maybe Kevin, this is for you. How much is Mobile Order & Pay adding to the foo
componenttext: Just a quick question for me and thinking about the food attach and direct sales growth rates, because these are monstrous numbers. If we think about what's driving this -- and maybe Kevin, this is for you. How much is Mobile Order & Pay adding to the food sales? Is this innovation on product? Is it recipes, promotions through the MSR network? Is it the placement store with some of the remodeling that you've done? What do you think is driving these big food numbers? Is it the continued tweaks or expansion of Mobile Order & Pay that really keeps this going?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks a question, Keith. I'll get some color and then I'll hand over to Cliff to share some more color on it. I think believe number one, we've got a strategy around new locations that has investing in food and beverage innovation. I think number on
componenttext: Yes, thanks a question, Keith. I'll get some color and then I'll hand over to Cliff to share some more color on it. I think believe number one, we've got a strategy around new locations that has investing in food and beverage innovation. I think number one, it's driving it is as we've continued to tune the food portfolio, I think we're -- we certainly have dialed in in the morning day-part we've done to complement the food items with the breakfast sandwiches I think for lunch and afternoon day-part, the Bistro Boxes and how we're dialing in there. And then we're laying the foundation for evening. So I think it's number one, it's the innovate we've done in food and how that's been presented to the customer in the stores. I think that's the big part of it. Certainly, digital helps because we can target offerings to get customers to try new things. And so what we find is once we encourage trials, that starts to lead to repeatability. So let me hand it over to Cliff to add a little more color behind what we're doing in the store drive that.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Kevin. And Keith, it's really an ongoing program. We now have some authority in breakfast sandwich range. And we continue to refine both the product and our availability. And we enhance our skills at both offering the products to customers th
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Kevin. And Keith, it's really an ongoing program. We now have some authority in breakfast sandwich range. And we continue to refine both the product and our availability. And we enhance our skills at both offering the products to customers through this place and through the partner confidence in sharing the product. One of the changes we made in Q2 last year is we introduced a food benefit to partners in U.S  where working on shift, they could have free food. And that I think helped them build confidence. And it's followed best practice we have with beverage for many years. So they're very proud of the product. We are continuing to enhance that range, basing it on our breakfast but lunch. Box, as Kevin mentioned, has grown 65%. And we own that format, and we consider that another way that we can grow range. So it's about as having a confidence around food, having an authority around and working on quality, variety, availability and our selling skills of our partners. So all in all, it's going well, and we have a lot more runway to continue to build food.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and the personalization of the visual platform has allowed as a one-to-one marketing capabilities that's driving trial. And I think that's the key aspects of it. So thanks for the question.
componenttext: Yes, and the personalization of the visual platform has allowed as a one-to-one marketing capabilities that's driving trial. And I think that's the key aspects of it. So thanks for the question.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The question is on the partner investments that you've been doing in the Americas. And certainly, it's very evident in this quarter, as store operating expense was up 80 basis points year-over-year despite a 9% comps. So my question is how much do you vie
componenttext: The question is on the partner investments that you've been doing in the Americas. And certainly, it's very evident in this quarter, as store operating expense was up 80 basis points year-over-year despite a 9% comps. So my question is how much do you view that investment that you've been making in partners as a specific driver of comps over the past 4 quarters? And as we think about lapping some of the investments that made in the second quarter of 2016, does Starbucks have an opportunity to continue to invest in their partners, to continue to invest in margin as a way to get sales? Or can you achieve outsized sales levels and actually begin to get leverage on that line?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's Cliff. The investments we're making in our partners both in technology side to give the tools to improve the way be do the work and also in them as partners and the salaries and benefits, we are certainly seeing strengthening engagements, reduc
componenttext: John, it's Cliff. The investments we're making in our partners both in technology side to give the tools to improve the way be do the work and also in them as partners and the salaries and benefits, we are certainly seeing strengthening engagements, reduction in turnover as partner level, and you're seeing the opportunity to invest also in our us to capture more of the opportunity that presents itself. Certainly, it has helped us cope with the benefits from Mobile Order & Pay. And we have seen growth at peak times across all of our markets. And we see the strengthening in the weekend business. And this is what we've been investing in hours. We're investing in the quality and retention of our partners.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, I think I'd add if you recall when you go back to the second quarter of last year when we introduced these partner investments, we started to see an acceleration of the business in comps and profitability. that continued every quarter as we incr
componenttext: And John, I think I'd add if you recall when you go back to the second quarter of last year when we introduced these partner investments, we started to see an acceleration of the business in comps and profitability. that continued every quarter as we increased those investments. And I would argue this quarter is a further acceleration of that. Also in 2016, we're starting to make these partner and digital investment internationally. Not a big number in Q1, but as we move throughout the year, we're so convinced by the results that we're seeing in the U.S, we're started to do things in China, in Canada and in the U.K. So we're completely convinced it's all tied together.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Sharon from William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Sharon from William Blair.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, I think you alluded to potentially going a different route with the K-Cup in the future and maybe not partnering with Keurig. Can you give us some more detail on what that might look like as it relates to Starbucks, either from on the upside cost
componenttext: Howard, I think you alluded to potentially going a different route with the K-Cup in the future and maybe not partnering with Keurig. Can you give us some more detail on what that might look like as it relates to Starbucks, either from on the upside cost perspective or on a margin perspective?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me say it this way. Regardless of what we decide to do, there would be no dilution whatsoever in our current ability to deliver to the market or retain the margin, which has been attractive since we started. We are in a unique position. We have the le
componenttext: Let me say it this way. Regardless of what we decide to do, there would be no dilution whatsoever in our current ability to deliver to the market or retain the margin, which has been attractive since we started. We are in a unique position. We have the leading share. We know customers buy the brewer because of Starbucks. And so we it's a wait-and-see situation. the most important thing is we're reaffirming to the market and our customers they have a ongoing K-Cups and there will have no dilution whatsoever in terms of our ability to maintain supply, regardless of who's making it.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Dave Palmer from RBC Capital.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering about the learnings from Mobile Order & Pay as it's now fully rolled out across the country and has been in some areas like the Pacific Northwest for many months. Specifically, how incremental do you think it's been to your same-store sales? And
componenttext: Wondering about the learnings from Mobile Order & Pay as it's now fully rolled out across the country and has been in some areas like the Pacific Northwest for many months. Specifically, how incremental do you think it's been to your same-store sales? And in what way would there be new users frequency or check? And has it continued to build in the first markets like the Northwest?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. This is Adam. So first of all, I'll take the second question first regarding incrementality. We're not breaking that out. Of course, global Order & Pay orders are driving incrementality, particularly at our busiest stores at peak. We're see
componenttext: Thanks, David. This is Adam. So first of all, I'll take the second question first regarding incrementality. We're not breaking that out. Of course, global Order & Pay orders are driving incrementality, particularly at our busiest stores at peak. We're seeing incremental occasions that come from the convenience itself, throughput efficiency line blocking benefits that we've seeing. in busiest stores in particular, we're seeing the incrementality we hoped for. in terms of learnings, I can that we have just scratched the surface in terms of our ability to promote Mobile Order & Pay, provide trial to our customers because we're seeing great conversions on trial. that's one learning. we've got robust road map for additional features over the course of the rest of the year, including the ability to trend -- for a user earn My Starbucks Rewards in Mobile Order & Pay flow, the ability to favorite stores and favorite items, and of course suggested and recommended , which will be a great thing for improving attach. So all those things as a result of the learnings, and you'll see us roll those out in the course of they year.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And add one thing as it relates to China specifically, having in China with John and I over the last week or so, I think there's one significant difference between the young people in China and evolution of mobile in the U.S. And that is the Chinese consu
componenttext: And add one thing as it relates to China specifically, having in China with John and I over the last week or so, I think there's one significant difference between the young people in China and evolution of mobile in the U.S. And that is the Chinese consumer has leapfrogged from a rotary phone to a regular phone to a cell phone and a smartphone overnight. And as a result of that, not if, but when we roll out Mobile Order & Pay as mobile payment in China, the adoption that we believe are going to have in China is going to be more significant and quicker than it has been in the U.S. which already has stunned us in terms of how quickly this consumer has embraced it. Our growth in China is not only in terms of the 500 stores per year that we're going to add over the next 5 years, it's overlaying that growth with technology that we strongly believe that's going to be adopted at a quicker pace than the U.S. consumer has as to how technology is embedded in the Chinese consumer's life.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Want to take the investments?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. thanks, Jason. It's Scott. so in the first quarter, The vast majority of our partner and digital investments were in the U.S., as I stated. And it is about 120 basis points, so you can do the math on revenue, but that's the number. For the full year, the vast majority still is in the U.S , although as we get into the back part of it, we'll talk about other segments. And its $275 million to $300 million for the full year.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Matt?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: We don't have a specific announcement to make early on in the partnership. But what I can tell you is we are confident we have significant new partnerships that we will be announcing in the coming quarters. And it will -- fulfill our vision to make Stars everywhere, the ability for customers and then Stars everywhere part of the Starbucks Experience.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions just on Mobile Ordering and digital in general purpose. First, I'm just following up on the comments about kind of generous next generation of the app. Are there certain milestones next quarter, for example, generation 2 coming out that
componenttext: I have 2 questions just on Mobile Ordering and digital in general purpose. First, I'm just following up on the comments about kind of generous next generation of the app. Are there certain milestones next quarter, for example, generation 2 coming out that allows, for example, to suggest upselling? Or do you think you have the way to amass several of them to kind of roll it out just because consumers don't want to keep updating their apps all the time to get the latest? And secondly, related to that, those that are engaged in digital platforms have seen tipping point where adoption accelerates significantly. And also you've also got an accelerated labor benefits. have to remove certain amount of labor in the store because it's coming in . You're getting digital orders or whatever. have a sense for tipping points for both revenue and for labor, or if Starbucks have already reached them or when you might expect to reach them?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam?
componenttext: Adam?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Adam. First of all in terms of waiting for features, w1 not planning on doing that. the way we approach it is we're constantly at work, adding new features in the U.S. and around the globe on both our iOS and Android platform. so you saw that just
componenttext: This is Adam. First of all in terms of waiting for features, w1 not planning on doing that. the way we approach it is we're constantly at work, adding new features in the U.S. and around the globe on both our iOS and Android platform. so you saw that just in the last week as we not only launched the Spotify integration in the U.S, but we also added Mobile Order & Pay to Android in the U.K. and Canada, also just in the last week. So you can see how busy we are. The future enhancements to Mobile Ordering that I mentioned are going to happen when those features are raised. We're going to happen over the last of the year. We're not going to bunch them up. so you'll see those happen on a continual basis. it's really the tipping point. I would say we're just continuing to see acceleration of Mobile Order & Pay. As Kevin mentioned in his remarks, we -- this been happening from the beginning. And we saw acceleration through the first quarter even into January, it's now up to 6 million mobile orders per month run rate, and we anticipate expect that to continue. And I also mentioned that we're just scratching the surface in terms of awareness and trial. So I think we're still approaching the tipping point, frankly.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, john, I just want to add one thing to that and it relates the incremental we're seeing in Mobile Order & Pay. So Kevin talked about in the U.S. business, we saw the fastest morning day-part revenue growth than we've seen in over 5 years, so biggest m
componenttext: Hey, john, I just want to add one thing to that and it relates the incremental we're seeing in Mobile Order & Pay. So Kevin talked about in the U.S. business, we saw the fastest morning day-part revenue growth than we've seen in over 5 years, so biggest morning day-part number in over 5 years. And we can trace back to a good portion of that uptick in performance this quarter our busiest stores. and busiest stores, we can trace that back to Mobile Order & Pay introduction. so it's aligned with we're seeing in our results. It's aligned with day-part. I would argue it's aligned with food attach and capacity, and we're just getting started.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to -- it's Cliff, to your point on tipping point labor, I would say what's most exciting of all is these higher-volume stores that are seeing the greatest adoption and usage of Mobile Order & Pay, which is capacity and it's allowing us to reach volume
componenttext: And to -- it's Cliff, to your point on tipping point labor, I would say what's most exciting of all is these higher-volume stores that are seeing the greatest adoption and usage of Mobile Order & Pay, which is capacity and it's allowing us to reach volumes in those stores that have set new levels for us. So I think that tipping point is happening in some stores. And it's happening in the a real meaningful way in high-volume stores, which is great. And in terms of labor, we're not looking at it that way. We're looking at using the labor to continually have the customers over there, continue to build relationships with our customers and just enhance the experience. So I think it's a continuous process of check and adjust, increase capacity on the store, hopefully have more Mobile Order & Pay orders, grow our labor accordingly. And that's the way we're looking at it.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Charles from Cowen.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Howard or Adam, just following up on an earlier point. As you look back over the last 7 years the trajectory of mobile payment sales growth, do you believe with the digital infrastructure have in place as well as consumer awareness your digital prowess, should lead mobile growth in mobile ordering and sales mix to directionally outpace the growth you experienced in your mobile payment sales?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Can't give you the specifics of that, but clearly, we're already demonstrating, if you look at the trajectory of these numbers, there's no question this segment of business and this foundation of the ecosystem we're building is going to outgrow the b
componenttext: Yes. Can't give you the specifics of that, but clearly, we're already demonstrating, if you look at the trajectory of these numbers, there's no question this segment of business and this foundation of the ecosystem we're building is going to outgrow the business. And that is going to to have a significant effect on the overall growth of the business, both in the U.S. and around the world. going back to China, I think having come back there, I think we are -- we just can't wait to introduce mobile payment, Mobile Order & Pay in China because it's going to be a success.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. let me just add to what Howard said on China in the Mobile Order & Payment there. We are seeing just with the Starbucks card that over 40% of our transactions are coming through China on the Starbucks Card. And that gives us great optimism a
componenttext: This is John. let me just add to what Howard said on China in the Mobile Order & Payment there. We are seeing just with the Starbucks card that over 40% of our transactions are coming through China on the Starbucks Card. And that gives us great optimism around what mobile order payment can be in China. So we're very bullish on that.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is -- Ryan here. just in terms of segments, the way we look at it, our core customer growth is strong. the loyalty customers, who have people participating MSR, is growing significantly faster than regular customer base. People using the mobile form
componenttext: This is -- Ryan here. just in terms of segments, the way we look at it, our core customer growth is strong. the loyalty customers, who have people participating MSR, is growing significantly faster than regular customer base. People using the mobile form of loyalty is growing even faster than that. And people using Mobile Order & Pay is growing even faster than that. So you actually see a cumulative benefit to the ecosystem .

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Karen Short from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Karen Short from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on China. I guess first question is can you give some color what the impact of Japan would have been on comps or CAP comps? And I guess within the China comp I'm wondering at this stage if you'd be willing to break out the comp
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on China. I guess first question is can you give some color what the impact of Japan would have been on comps or CAP comps? And I guess within the China comp I'm wondering at this stage if you'd be willing to break out the comp by day-part, so morning, afternoon and evening? And any color how that's evolved over the last several quarters?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't break out comps by country within this segment. Let me say it this way. We have over 10 consecutive years of positive comps and positive traffic in China. The success we're enjoying in China is really kind of highlighted by this past quarter. We'
componenttext: We don't break out comps by country within this segment. Let me say it this way. We have over 10 consecutive years of positive comps and positive traffic in China. The success we're enjoying in China is really kind of highlighted by this past quarter. We've opened over 150 stores in China this past quarter, the most we've ever opened in our history, and it was the strongest glass new stores we have ever opened. In terms of day-part, I think in addition to technology with everyone that there will be introducing in China, perhaps the most exciting aspect of core China business looking to the future is that we're sitting with incredibly strong level of unit economics in Tier 1, Tier 2, Tier 3, Tier 4 cities that are now almost 100 cities in China. And we're doing that for the most part without truly establishing a morning ritual. And there's no doubt in our mind, if we look at every market we've opened around the world including those markets in China, that a morning ritual starts, it evolves and it occurs. And we're seeing it sporadically, but enough to give us great -- not hope, but vindication in those stores that are open the longest, Beijing and Shanghai, how that is developing. so if you look of the unit economics in China today, which are incredibly attractive, and you lay on technology we talked about, and then the morning ritual's going to come, we are sitting in a business today that I said when I was in China last week, that we believe one day could very well be larger than the U.S. business. anyone on the call who is in any way dissuaded by our commitment and our success in China as a result of the 5% comp in the region is not only mistaken, but you are looking at the wrong metric.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Tarantino from Robert W Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Tarantino from Robert W Baird.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, you talked in the past about the shift from brick-and-mortar retail to online retail creating some headwinds in the holidays for all retailers and perhaps for Starbucks. So just wondering if you could talk about how your business trended during ho
componenttext: Howard, you talked in the past about the shift from brick-and-mortar retail to online retail creating some headwinds in the holidays for all retailers and perhaps for Starbucks. So just wondering if you could talk about how your business trended during holidays specifically? And perhaps, how you exited the quarter relative to some of those headwind you've talked about in the past?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a perfect question for me. So I think we said 3 years ago publicly that we began to envision that there would be a seismic change in consumer behavior. And that seismic change was due, in large part, to e-commerce and smartphone shopping. I think t
componenttext: That's a perfect question for me. So I think we said 3 years ago publicly that we began to envision that there would be a seismic change in consumer behavior. And that seismic change was due, in large part, to e-commerce and smartphone shopping. I think today in numbers you've seen just the last 3 weeks, store closures of almost 50 Macy's stores, 150 Walmart stores, you got to ask yourself, what's going to happen to the future of many of those malls that are anchored by those big-box retailers? Having said that, the investments that we made in our partner investments, which is store execution and retention of our people and the intimate relationship we have with the customer, coupled with the technology investments which have been significant, to put up 4% traffic in this environment when there isn't a retailer in country that is putting up anything close to 1% or 2%, let alone 9% comps in the quarter in the U.S. business. And we finished very strong for the quarter. So we -- we've insulated ourselves from the bricks-and-mortar problem that were  -- will face many retailers as a result of the experience that we've created, the innovation both in product, partner investments and technology. And as people who have covered the company know, we are still opening fantastic stores in the U.S. on a base of almost 10,000. And in addition to what I said about China and 150 stores that we opened best of class, the stores that we opened in the U.S  this year are also best of class terms of revenue and return on investment. So we see no signs whatsoever that we are going to hit in any way by the seismic change in consumer behavior because we invested ahead of the growth curve, and we continue to invest in those things that are customer-facing, partner-facing and technology.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Nicole Miller Regan from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Nicole Miller Regan from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: When you look at the Channel Development business, what's your long-term revenue and margin opportunity? And do you imagine that it comes from or envision new and existing platforms? And if new, how can we think about that?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nicole, I'll start and I think Mike can jump in the second part of the question. What we see over long term is double-digit revenue growth in channels every year and moderate margin expansion, driven by leveraging cost of goods sold and overall operating
componenttext: Nicole, I'll start and I think Mike can jump in the second part of the question. What we see over long term is double-digit revenue growth in channels every year and moderate margin expansion, driven by leveraging cost of goods sold and overall operating beverage. Mike, do you want to take the rest?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take rest. So our future performance is going to build on what you're seeing this quarter. So in the U.S., you will continue to see strength of our existing coffee business just based on the level of innovation, the loyalty we have and the opp
componenttext: Yes, let me take rest. So our future performance is going to build on what you're seeing this quarter. So in the U.S., you will continue to see strength of our existing coffee business just based on the level of innovation, the loyalty we have and the opportunity, quite honestly, for us to connect with our My Starbucks Reward down the aisle even more. What we haven't talked as much about yet and that is coming is the activity we have on the international front. So you heard me talk about many of the partnerships that you just created in China and also in Latin America. That is primarily already to drink business for us, so we're going to beverage the strength that we've seen in the U.S. and the insights live on with our partnership within the North American coffee partnership interest rate into that growing business from ready-to-drink perspective internationally.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Bernstein from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Bernstein from Barclays.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions. One in the European business or EMEA, I'm just wondering if we can talk a bit about the softening that you saw? I didn't realize the magnitude or the impact it had on the broader European comp in terms of the obviously tragic Paris attac
componenttext: Just 2 questions. One in the European business or EMEA, I'm just wondering if we can talk a bit about the softening that you saw? I didn't realize the magnitude or the impact it had on the broader European comp in terms of the obviously tragic Paris attacks. I'm just wondering if you can give some color maybe what those trends are running pre- and post, and whether it impacted other markets? Just wanted to get a feel for whether it's kind of a broader macro issue, and if anything you think is going on just within the Starbucks numbers? And separately, Scott, I'm just wondering if we can give an update on just the balance of the dividend versus the share repo and also some on leverage. I know you talked a lot about returning incremental cash to the share purchase and obviously the dividends. Just any updated thoughts on that would be great.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Kevin. I'll take the first question, and I'll handle it over to Scott for the second one. Fundamentally what we saw as we tracked our comps in France, Germany and U.K., large cities in France, Germany and U.K., I think there was a shift in co
componenttext: Yes, this is Kevin. I'll take the first question, and I'll handle it over to Scott for the second one. Fundamentally what we saw as we tracked our comps in France, Germany and U.K., large cities in France, Germany and U.K., I think there was a shift in consumer behavior that showed transaction comps flat or down slightly across large cities in France, Germany and U.K. In this last week or so, we've seen evidence that, that consumer behavior is recovering. I wouldn't read it more into it than that. Scott?

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll add 2 things, one to what Kevin just said. Just as we look at the international segments, EMEA and CAP, this year and over the long term, we expect significant revenue and margin expansion to continue. So if you look at EMEA for example, a few y
componenttext: Yes, I'll add 2 things, one to what Kevin just said. Just as we look at the international segments, EMEA and CAP, this year and over the long term, we expect significant revenue and margin expansion to continue. So if you look at EMEA for example, a few years ago, they were at breakeven. Margin was essentially 0. And we're guiding to 15% this year, which is over 100 basis point improvement over last year. And as I said, we're going that toward 20% over next handful of years in EMEA. And so that's a market with significant profitability growth. So to your question, October looked like a really good month to us. And it looked like we were right on track with what we expected for the year. And then after what happened in Paris, we see some softening. And now it's coming back. so full year, we haven't changed our guidance. And we're not at all changing in the long term, our belief in what we can do and what we have been driving in EMEA. And then CAP again, we've targeted around 20% this year on operating margin, which is up slightly despite the math that impacts us from the Japan acquisition. And I actually think in CAP, you'll see us move us up to low to mid-20s over 5 years or so from an operating margin perspective, which gets the CAP right up of there with the Americas business. So again strong revenue growth, we'll have mid-teen revenue growth in CAP this year. The numbers are phenomenal. Japan has outperformed the model in every single aspect we can look at since acquisition. And we're just getting started in during that business with the team over there. Howard talked about our China, and again, we've never been more bullish in that. So international markets for the quarter had a good quarter, and the outlook for the future is strong. As far as the balance sheet goes, we did a little bit more buyback than dividend in that split I gave you. But I just want to remind you, Jeff, that given what we saw in the holiday and what we saw in the equity markets, we significantly increased our buybacks to t the tune of roughly double already this quarter what we did in the whole quarter last year. So that will include some leverage on the balance sheet. We'll continue to evaluate that as we go forward. If you look back over the last 12 months, we've returned $2.5 billion cash to shareholders. That number is significant. And over the last few quarters, that's number increased as we put the balance sheet to work a little harder as we discussed.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Karen, this is John. we did not see seasonality come into the business in the quarter. Like Howard said, we continue to see very strong transaction growth. We had record number of store openings in China and then also across the region. And we remain very bullish on the opportunity that we have going forward. Right now, we're in the throes of the Chinese New Year, and we're very optimistic on what that's going to bring.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, one of the reasons the G&A as a percentage of revenue is a little lower than you may have modeled is last year, we had a fair bit of expense in G&A related to the Japan acquisition. And that was deal-related costs and some of the integration costs, an
componenttext: No, one of the reasons the G&A as a percentage of revenue is a little lower than you may have modeled is last year, we had a fair bit of expense in G&A related to the Japan acquisition. And that was deal-related costs and some of the integration costs, and they were highest in the first quarter. So if you were modeling it as a percentage of revenue, that could explain the delta you're seeing.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Mike, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Starbucks Coffee Company's First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  Ms. Doraisamy, you may begin your conference.

headline: Starbucks Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. This is Durga Doraisamy, Director of Investor Relations for Starbucks Coffee Company. Thank you for joining us today to discuss our first quarter 2016 results, which will be led by Howard Schultz, Chairman and CE
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. This is Durga Doraisamy, Director of Investor Relations for Starbucks Coffee Company. Thank you for joining us today to discuss our first quarter 2016 results, which will be led by Howard Schultz, Chairman and CEO; Kevin Johnson, President and COO; Michael Conway, President, Global Channel Development; and Scott Maw, CFO. Joining us for Q&A are Cliff Burrows, Group President, U.S., Americas and Teavana; John Culver, Group President, China/Asia Pacific, Channel Development and Emerging Brands; Matt Ryan, Global Chief Strategy Officer; and Adam Brotman, Chief Digital Officer. 
This conference call will include forward-looking statements which are subject to various risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from these statements. Any such statements should be considered in conjunction with cautionary statements in our earnings release and risk factor discussions in our filings with the SEC, including our last annual report on Form 10-K. Starbucks assumes no obligation to update any of these forward-looking statements or information.
